rev.diff:
Line 353: Line 353:
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising]</ref>
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising]</ref>
â
=== 15 February and later ===
+
=== 15 February ===
  +
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
[[Tarek El-Bishry]], a retired judge known for his pro-opposition views and for his support for a strong independent judiciary, was tasked with setting up the [[Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011|committee to reform the constitution]].<ref name="ReferenceA">http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121563130198336.html</ref> The changes would be formally announced within ten days.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12466893</ref>
[[Tarek El-Bishry]], a retired judge known for his pro-opposition views and for his support for a strong independent judiciary, was tasked with setting up the [[Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011|committee to reform the constitution]].<ref name="ReferenceA">http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121563130198336.html</ref> The changes would be formally announced within ten days.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12466893</ref>
Adly Fayed, the director of public security at the interior ministry, and Ismail El Shaer, Cairo's security chief, have been fired over their decision to open fire on the demonstrators.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Adly Fayed, the director of public security at the interior ministry, and Ismail El Shaer, Cairo's security chief, have been fired over their decision to open fire on the demonstrators.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Line 359: Line 359:
[[Amr Moussa]] announced on 15 February that he would run in the presidential election.<ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7288055.html</ref> The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced on the same day that it would form a party to run in the parliamentary elections.<ref>http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028941,00.html</ref>
[[Amr Moussa]] announced on 15 February that he would run in the presidential election.<ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7288055.html</ref> The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced on the same day that it would form a party to run in the parliamentary elections.<ref>http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028941,00.html</ref>
  +
=== 17 February ===
  +
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
The army stated on 17 February 2011 it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] and former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], as well as steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968</ref>
The army stated on 17 February 2011 it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] and former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], as well as steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968</ref>
  +
=== 18 February â Friday of Victory ===
  +
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
On 18 January, influential Muslim cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]], who arrived in Egypt after decades of exile in [[Qatar]], led the "Victory Day" Friday sermon in Tahrir Square attended by hundreds of thousands of people, while Qaradawi's guards barred [[Wael Ghonim]] from joining him on stage.<ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/Egypt-protest-hero-Wael-Ghonim-barred-from-stage/Article1-663996.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0218/Egypt-revolution-unfinished-Qaradawi-tells-Tahrir-masses</ref><ref>http://en.trend.az/regions/met/arabicr/1832138.html</ref>
On 18 January, influential Muslim cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]], who arrived in Egypt after decades of exile in [[Qatar]], led the "Victory Day" Friday sermon in Tahrir Square attended by hundreds of thousands of people, while Qaradawi's guards barred [[Wael Ghonim]] from joining him on stage.<ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/Egypt-protest-hero-Wael-Ghonim-barred-from-stage/Article1-663996.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0218/Egypt-revolution-unfinished-Qaradawi-tells-Tahrir-masses</ref><ref>http://en.trend.az/regions/met/arabicr/1832138.html</ref>
